item.title: Day 13: SOC Analyst Challenge
item.description:
Day 13: How To Install Elastic Agent on Ubuntu Link to heading

Ressources :MyDFIR Channel

Prerequisites Link to heading

  1. An Ubuntu Server (22.04 LTS or 24.04 LTS) with internet access.
  2. A Running Elastic Stack: Kibana and Elasticsearch must be running and accessible.
  3. A Running Fleet Server: You must have a Fleet Server instance already set up and enrolled. The Ubuntu agent will connect to this Fleet Server.
  4. Credentials: You need a valid Enrollment Token generated from Kibana.

Installation Method: Using Fleet in Kibana Link to heading

This is the simplest and most reliable method, as it provides you with a ready-to-use command.

item.title: Day 12: SOC Analyst Challenge
item.description:
Day 12: Ubuntu Server 24.02 Installation (SSH-server) Link to heading

Ressources :MyDFIR Channel

Prerequisites Link to heading

  1. VMware Fusion:
  2. Ubuntu Server ISO: Download the latest 24.04 LTS version from the official Ubuntu Download page.

Step 1: Create a New Virtual Machine Link to heading

  1. Open VMware Fusion.
  2. From the menu bar, click File > New.
  3. Select Create a custom virtual machine. Click Continue.
  4. Choose Operating System:
    • Select Linux.
    • From the Version dropdown, choose Ubuntu 64-bit.
    • Click Continue.
  5. Choose Firmware: Select UEFI (recommended). Click Continue.
  6. Virtual Disk: Choose SCSI (recommended). Click Continue.
  7. Create Disk: Select Create a new virtual disk. Set the size (e.g., 25 GB is a good minimum). Choose Split into multiple files. Click Continue.

Step 2: Configure Hardware Before Installation Link to heading

Crucial Step: Before clicking Finish, you must configure the VM to boot from the ISO.

item.title: Day 11: SOC Analyst Challenge
item.description:
Day 11: What is a Brute Force Attack? Link to heading

Ressources :MyDFIR Channel

A Brute Force Attack is a simple yet powerful hacking method where an attacker tries to gain access to a system, account, or encrypted file by systematically trying every possible combination of credentials (like passwords or encryption keys) until the correct one is found.

Think of it like a thief trying to break into a locked building by trying every key on a giant keychain, one by one.

item.title: Day 10: SOC Analyst Challenge
item.description:
Day 10: Elasticsearch Ingest Data Tutorial Link to heading

Ressources :MyDFIR Channel

This tutorial covers how to ingest specific Windows Event Logs (Sysmon and filtered Windows Defender) using Elastic Agent integrations.

Part 1: Add the Custom Log Integration for Sysmon Link to heading

  1. Navigate to Integrations: In Kibana (http://172.16.193.153:5601), go to Management > Integrations.

  2. Browse for Integration: In the search bar, type “costum windows event logs”.

item.title: Day 9: SOC Analyst Challenge
item.description:
Day 9: Sysmon Setup Tutorial Link to heading

Ressources :MyDFIR Channel

Sysmon Setup Tutorial Link to heading

Part 1: Download Sysmon Link to heading

  1. Go to the official Microsoft Sysinternals page: Download Sysmon
  2. Download the ZIP file and extract it to a folder on your Windows machine .

Part 2: Get a Security-Focused Configuration File Link to heading

Running Sysmon with its default config generates too much noise. We use a config file to tell it what to log and filter out benign activity.

item.title: Day 8: SOC Analyst Challenge
item.description:
Day 8: What is Sysmon? Link to heading

Ressources :MyDFIR Channel

Of course. Here is a clear explanation of what Sysmon is.

Sysmon (System Monitor) is a free, lightweight system service and device driver for Microsoft Windows, created by Microsoft. It’s part of the Windows Sysinternals suite of tools.

Its primary purpose is not to prevent attacks but to provide incredibly detailed, high-quality logs about system activity. Think of it as a surveillance camera for your Windows operating system.

item.title: Day 7: SOC Analyst Challenge
item.description:
Day 7: Elastic Agent and Fleet Server Setup Tutorial Link to heading

Ressources : MyDFIR Channel

Architecture Overview Link to heading

  • ELK Server (IP: 172.16.193.153): Runs Elasticsearch and Kibana. Fleet management is done here.
  • Fleet Server Host (IP: 172.16.193.157): A dedicated server (Linux) that runs the Fleet Server component.
  • Windows Server 2022 Host (IP: 172.16.193.155): The server we want to monitor, which will run the Elastic Agent.

Part 1: Prerequisites - The ELK Server Link to heading

Ensure your ELK server (172.16.193.153) is fully operational and accessible.

item.title: Day 6: SOC Analyst Challenge
item.description:
Day 6: Elastic Agent and Fleet Server Introduction Link to heading

Ressources : MyDFIR Channel

Elastic Agent and Fleet Server: A Centralized Management Revolution Link to heading

1. The Problem They Solve Link to heading

Traditionally, collecting logs, metrics, and security data from servers involved installing multiple lightweight data shippers (like Beats: Filebeat, Metricbeat, Winlogbeat, etc.) and managing each one individually. This approach became complex and hard to maintain at scale:

item.title: Day 5: SOC Analyst Challenge
item.description:
Day 5: Windows Server 2022 Installation Link to heading

Ressources : MyDFIR Channel

Part 1: The Installation Link to heading

Go to Windows Server 2022 ISO and select the ISO option for your desired edition (e.g., Standard),

1. Open VMware Fusion and Start Creation Link to heading

  • Launch VMware Fusion.
  • From the menu bar, click File > New.
  • Click Create a custom virtual machine. This gives you full control over the configuration. Click Continue.

2. Choose Operating System Link to heading

  • Select Windows as the guest operating system.
  • From the Version dropdown, scroll down and select Windows Server 2022 or Windows Server 2022 (64-bit).
  • Click Continue.

3. Choose Firmware Type Link to heading

  • Select UEFI (Highly recommended for modern Windows systems). Click Continue.

4. Choose Virtual Disk Type Link to heading

  • Select NVMe (recommended for performance) or SCSI. Click Continue.

5. Create a New Virtual Disk Link to heading

  • Ensure Create a new virtual disk is selected.
  • Set the maximum disk size. 80 GB is a good starting point for a server with a GUI.
  • Choose Split into multiple files (recommended for portability).
  • Click Continue.

6. Finalize Creation & Configure Settings Link to heading

  • Before clicking Finish: Uncheck the box for Power on this virtual machine after creation.
  • Click Customize Settings.
  • A save dialog will appear. Name your VM (e.g., Win-Server-2022) and choose a location. Click Save.

7. Configure Virtual Machine Hardware Link to heading

A settings window will open. Configure the following key components:

item.title: Day 4: SOC Analyst Challenge
item.description:
Day 4: Installing Kibana Link to heading

Ressources : MyDFIR Channel

  1. Download the Package

    • Go to the official Kibana Download page.
    • Under “Linux x86_64”, right-click on the DEB package link and select Copy Link Address.

    The version number in the link might be different (e.g., 9.1.3).

  2. Download on Your Ubuntu Server

    Open a terminal on your Ubuntu server and use wget with the copied link to download the package.

item.title: Day 3: SOC Analyst Challenge
item.description:
Day 3: ELK Stack Istallation Link to heading

Ressources : MyDFIR Channel

Create private network Link to heading

  1. Open VMware Fusion Preferences

    • Launch VMware Fusion.
    • From the menu bar, navigate to Window > Virtual Machine Library.
    • With the library open, go to the VMware Fusion menu in the menu bar and click Preferences….

  2. Access the Network Settings

    In the Preferences window, click on the Network icon (it resembles a globe with a network cable).

item.title: Day 2: SOC Analyst Challenge
item.description:
Day 2: ELK Stack Introduction Link to heading

Ressources : MyDFIR Channel First of all the ‘E’ stands for Elastic Search. Elasticsearch is an open source, distributed search and analytics engine built for speed, scale, and AI applications. As a retrieval platform, it stores structured, unstructured, and vector data in real time — delivering fast hybrid and vector search, powering observability and security analytics, and enabling AI-driven applications with high performance, accuracy, and relevance.

Objectives: Link to heading

  • how to attack, detect and ivestigate
  • how to create alerts ad dashboards
  • how to setup and investigate ticketing system

Day 1: Create diagrams, logical setup that will serve as the foundation for this 30-Day challenge Link to heading

Day 2: ELK Stack Introduction Link to heading

First of all the ‘E’ stands for Elastic Search. Elasticsearch is an open source, distributed search and analytics engine built for speed, scale, and AI applications. As a retrieval platform, it stores structured, unstructured, and vector data in real time — delivering fast hybrid and vector search, powering observability and security analytics, and enabling AI-driven applications with high performance, accuracy, and relevance.

item.title: Creating a Blog with GitHub Pages and Hugo Template
item.description:
Creating a Blog with GitHub Pages and Hugo Link to heading

This comprehensive tutorial exists to fill a gap. During my own journey of building a blog with Hugo and GitHub Pages, I discovered that most available guides were either outdated, fragmented, or skipped crucial steps.

This markdown file includes:

  1. introduction
  2. Prerequisites
  3. Steps
  4. Conclusion
  5. Additional Resources

Introduction Link to heading

In this tutorial, I’ll walk you through the process of creating a static blog using Hugo and deploying it to GitHub Pages. This combination provides a fast, free, and easy way to host your blog.

item.title: Create blog github pages with hugo
Markdown Syntax Guide
item.description: article offers a sample of basic Markdown syntax that can be used in Hugo content files, also it shows whether basic HTML elements are decorated with CSS in a Hugo theme.

item.title: Rich Content
item.description:
Hugo ships with several Built-in Shortcodes for rich content, along with a Privacy Config and a set of Simple Shortcodes that enable static and no-JS versions of various social media embeds.

Link to heading

item.title: More Rich Content
item.description:
Hugo Coder provides some Custom Shortcodes.

Link to heading

item.title: Math Typesetting
item.description: Mathematical notation in a Hugo project can be enabled by using third party JavaScript libraries.

item.title: HTML and CSS only tabs
item.description:
Shortcodes Link to heading

The following content:

{{< tabgroup >}}
{{< tab name="Hello" >}}
Hello World!
{{< /tab >}}

{{< tab name="Goodbye" >}}
Goodbye Everybody!
{{< /tab >}}
{{< /tabgroup >}}

Will generate:

Hello World!
Goodbye Everybody!

Right alignment Link to heading

You can also align the tabs to the right:

item.title: Mermaid JS support
item.description:
If you want to use Mermaid-JS on your website. Provide mermaid as Shortcode in your markdown file.

flowchart LR A --> B B --> C C --> D D --> B
sequenceDiagram participant Alice participant Bob Alice->>Bob: Hi Bob Bob->>Alice: Hi Alice

Find more example on Mermaid-JS website.
